Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Through the accidental release prevention program, Crown Bakery regularly evaluates the need for any changes to improve safety. Currently, Crown Bakery is implementing several updates of older equipment and is considering updating other systems that will continue to improve safety. As mentioned above, two open seal ammonia pumps are scheduled to be replaced in 2021.

ocation in Nashville, TN for several years. Until November of 2020, Crown Bakeries was operating the ammonia system with less than the threshold quantity of anhydrous ammonia. A major expansion of the business in November of 2020, required more ammonia to be added to the system to operate additional equipment; driving the total quantity of ammonia over the TQ of 10,000 pounds. Prior to becoming a PSM facility, Crown Bakeries had one reportable ammonia leak incident in 2017. At the time of this ammonia occurrence, Crown Bakeries followed proper leak reporting procedures and carried out an Incident Investigation. The Incident Investigation findings indicated that a failure of a seal on the oil reservoir of an ammonia pump caused the release. 1,623 pounds of ammonia was released from the ammonia pump into the compressor room. Ventilation fans were used to dissipate the ammonia until ammonia concentrations were back to normal, safe levels. Recommendations derived from the Incident Investigation, stated that the open seal ammonia pumps should be replaced with enclosed seal ammonia pumps that are much less likely to experience leaks. Crown Bakeries followed through on that recommendation and replaced the open seal pumps with enclosed seal pumps. Two open seal pumps still exist, but they are not in operation. These remaining open seal pumps are scheduled to be replaced in 2021. The PHA took this prior incident under consideration and specific What-If questions addressed safety concerns with these types of ammonia pumps and ammonia pumps in general.
Emergency Response Program
Crown Bakery's employees have not been trained to be Emergency Responders and will not respond to emergency ammonia releases; however, the system can be shut down by activating one of the EMERGENCY STOP (E-STOP) switches located outside the Engine Room doors. An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) has been developed that includes coordination with local, county, state, and national responders. Procedures f

r implementing, maintaining, and conducting the various duties associated with the PSM program; to ensure it stays current and effectively protects the employees, the business, and the community.
Written plans for implementing Employee Participation in PSM.
Process Safety Information: Information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process and the equipment in the process. 
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): A PHA review of the ammonia refrigeration process was conducted to identify hazards and safeguards pertaining to the ammonia refrigeration system.
Operating procedures were developed and implemented for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.
Safe work practices were developed and implemented for lockout/tagout, confined space and opening equipment and piping (Line-Breaking Procedures). 
A Mechanical Integrity program is being implemented to maintain the on-going integrity and safety of the refrigeration system, including application of the following industry codes and standards: 
ASME Boiler & Pressure Valve Codes
ANSI B31.5 Piping Code
ANSI/IIAR 2 American National Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Closed-Circuit Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems
ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 15
NFPA guidelines for fire protection equipment
A Management of Change (MOC) program and procedures were developed to address all proposed changes to the refrigeration system.
Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) procedures were developed.
A detailed Compliance Audit checklist is used to evaluate compliance with the Process Safety Management and Risk Management programs every three years.
Developed Incident Investigation procedures to analyze and review accidents or near-misses involving the refrigeration system.
Hot Work Permit system.
Contractor management, a program to evaluate contractors and contractor employees.

Updated 3/30/21 to reflect the company's name change from the Bakery Cos. to Crown Bakeries.

Crown Bakeries RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Crown Bakeries, located at 1905 Hackworth Street in Nashville, TN 37210, is a producer of frozen bread dough and finished bread products.
At this facility, anhydrous ammonia (cas #7664-41-7) is used as a refrigerant to cool bread products for storage and processing. The refrigeration process at this facility is comprised of one closed-loop, mechanical refrigeration system. Liquid ammonia is supplied by pumps or pressure differential to the evaporators, roof-top air-handling unit, vessels, and heat exchangers. Ammonia vapor and liquid from the process equipment returns to the recirculators. The normal high-side operating pressure ranges from 120 to 190 psig. The maximum allowable high side working pressure is 300 psig.
As part of the PSM program, Crown Bakeries has completed a Process Hazard Analysis, developed written operating procedures, trained employees on ammonia and PSM awareness and system operation, established procedures to conduct Management of Change procedures and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews, and developed a Mechanical Integrity program for ammonia refrigeration equipment. In addition to the daily monitoring of the refrigeration process, Crown Bakeries has implemented an ongoing Preventive Maintenance program to ensure the refrigeration equipment and safety systems are maintained in good operating condition.
General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the RMP general accidental release prevention program, is being implemented by Crown Bakeries to address the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system at the Nashville, TN facility. The PSM program developed and implemented at Crown Bakeries includes the following steps:
